The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2011 into LegCo on 29 April 2011 to amend the various electoral and related arrangements for, among other things, returning CE and forming LegCo in accordance with the Chief Executive Election (Amendment) Ordinance 2011 and Legislative Council (Amendment) Ordinance 2011. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held six meetings and reported to the House Committee on 24 June 2011. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 6 July 2011. The Bill was passed by LegCo on the same date. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

ctxt: Subcommittee to study discrimination on the ground of sexual orientation
summ: The Subcommittee on the Nine Amendment Regulations made under the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance was formed on 20 May 2011. The Subcommittee held 4 meetings [Meeting schedules] to study the legislative amendments made to EAC Regulations concerning voter registration, electoral procedure and electoral arrangements. The Subcommittee made a Report to House Committee on 24 June 2011. [Report]

The Panel discussed the arrangements for filling vacancies in the Legislative Council and received views from deputations on the Administration's proposals. [Paper][Background brief prepared by the Secretariat][LegCo Brief]

The Administration introduced into LegCo the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 on 8 June 2011. The Bill sought to provide for the filling of any vacancy in the membership of LegCo arising during the term of office of LegCo by a replacement mechanism. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held nine meetings and reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 24 June 2011 and 10 February 2012 respectively. [Meeting schedules] [Report 1] [Report 2]

In response to the views of the bills committee formed to study the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 that the Administration should provide more time to consider Members' suggestions and listen further to the views of the public, the Administration published a consultation paper for conducting a two-month public consultation.  The public consultation ended on 24 September 2011.

The Panel discussed the Administration's Consultation Report on Arrangements for Filling Vacancies in the Legislative Council. The Administration wrote to the Bills Committee on 1 February 2012, advising that it would introduce a new Bill to implement the latest proposal, while the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 would not be further pursued and would be withdrawn. [Consultation Report] [Paper]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2012 into LegCo on 3 February 2012 to revise the regulation of election advertisements, make some necessary updates and modify arrangements for various elections. The House Committee meeting on 10 February 2012, a bills committee was formed to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held four meetings and reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 20 April 2012. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 9 May 2012. The Bill was passed by LegCo on the same date. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Administration introduced the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2012 into LegCo on 8 February 2012. The Bills sought to introduce a restriction to prohibit a person who had resigned, or was taken to had resigned, as a Member of LegCo from standing for a by-election to be held in the same LegCo term within six months of his resignation.

The Bills Committee held five meetings and reported to the House Committee on 20 April 2012. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 2 May 2012. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 1 June 2012. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2011 into LegCo on 29 April 2011 to amend the various electoral and related arrangements for, among other things, returning CE and forming LegCo in accordance with the Chief Executive Election (Amendment) Ordinance 2011 and Legislative Council (Amendment) Ordinance 2011. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held six meetings and reported to the House Committee on 24 June 2011. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 6 July 2011. The Bill was passed by LegCo on the same date. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

ctxt: Subcommittee to study discrimination on the ground of sexual orientation
summ: The Subcommittee on the Nine Amendment Regulations made under the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance was formed on 20 May 2011. The Subcommittee held 4 meetings [Meeting schedules] to study the legislative amendments made to EAC Regulations concerning voter registration, electoral procedure and electoral arrangements. The Subcommittee made a Report to House Committee on 24 June 2011. [Report]

The Panel discussed the arrangements for filling vacancies in the Legislative Council and received views from deputations on the Administration's proposals. [Paper][Background brief prepared by the Secretariat][LegCo Brief]

The Administration introduced into LegCo the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 on 8 June 2011. The Bill sought to provide for the filling of any vacancy in the membership of LegCo arising during the term of office of LegCo by a replacement mechanism. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held nine meetings and reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 24 June 2011 and 10 February 2012 respectively. [Meeting schedules] [Report 1] [Report 2]

In response to the views of the bills committee formed to study the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 that the Administration should provide more time to consider Members' suggestions and listen further to the views of the public, the Administration published a consultation paper for conducting a two-month public consultation.  The public consultation ended on 24 September 2011.

The Administration wrote to the Bills Committee on 1 February 2012, advising that it would introduce a new Bill to implement the latest proposal, while the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2011 would not be further pursued and would be withdrawn. [Consultation Report] [Paper]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2012 into LegCo on 3 February 2012 to revise the regulation of election advertisements, make some necessary updates and modify arrangements for various elections. The House Committee meeting on 10 February 2012, a bills committee was formed to study the Bill.

The Bills Committee held four meetings and reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 20 April 2012. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 9 May 2012. The Bill was passed by LegCo on the same date. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Administration introduced the LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2012 into LegCo on 8 February 2012. The Bills sought to introduce a restriction to prohibit a person who had resigned, or was taken to had resigned, as a Member of LegCo from standing for a by-election to be held in the same LegCo term within six months of his resignation.

The Bills Committee held five meetings and reported to the House Committee on 20 April 2012. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 2 May 2012. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 1 June 2012. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Administration introduced the District Councils (Amendment) Bill 2013 into LegCo on 20 February 2013, proposing amendments to the District Council Ordinance and other relevant subsidiary legislation with a view to abolishing the system of appointing members to DCs with effect from 1 January 2016, i.e. the commencement date of the fifth term of office of DCs. The Bills Committee held three meetings and reported to the House Committee on 3 May 2013. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 15 May 2013. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 22 May 2013. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2014 into LegCo on 16 April 2014. The Bills amends various pieces of electoral legislation to improve the elector and voter registration arrangements and the electoral procedures for the elections of the Chief Executive, Legislative Council, District Councils and the Rural Representative.

The Bills Committee held five meetings and reported to the House Committee on 20 June 2014. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 2 July 2014. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 10 July 2014. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

On 24 February 2015, the Chief Executive in Council made the District Councils Ordinance (Amendment of Schedule 7) Order 2015 in accordance with section 82 of the District Councils Ordinance (Cap. 547) to increase the subsidy rate of the financial assistance scheme for candidates of District Council elections; and also the Maximum Amount of Election Expenses (District Council Election) (Amendment) Regulation 2015 under section 45 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554) to increase the election expenses limit for District Council elections. The two pieces of subsidiary legislation were gazetted on 6 March 2015 and tabled at LegCo on 18 March 2015 for negative vetting. The House Committee agreed to form a subcommittee to study the Order and the Amendment Regulation. The Subcommittee held a meeting with the Administration and received views from the public on 9 April 2015. The Subcommittee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 24 April 2015. [Meeting schedule] [Report]
The Panel discussed the legislative amendments regarding the 2016 Legislative Council Election. [Paper] [Background brief prepared by the Secretariat]
The Panel discussed the operation of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance. [Paper] [Background brief prepared by the Secretariat]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2015 into LegCo on 22 April 2015. The Bill amends certain pieces of electoral legislation to introduce technical amendments concerning the lists of persons comprising certain functional constituencies ("FCs"), the name of a FC and a subsector, the list of constituents of a subsector, the registration of voters for a subsector and the counting procedure for a FC; and to make other minor amendments. The Bills Committee held four meetings and reported to the House Committee on 19 June 2015. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 8 July 2015. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 13 July 2015. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Declaration of Geographical Constituencies (Legislative Council) Order 2015 was gazetted on 16 October 2015 and tabled at LegCo on 28 October 2015 for negative vetting. The Order is made by the Chief Executive in Council under sections 18 and 19 of the LegCo Ordinance to declare areas of Hong Kong to be geographical constituencies ("GCs") for the purpose of electing Members for the Sixth LegCo, give names to those GCs and specify the number of Members to be returned for each of those GCs. The House Committee agreed to form a subcommittee to study the Order. The Subcommittee held a meeting with the Administration on 3 November 2015 and reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 13 November 2015. [EAC Report] [Meeting schedule] [Report]

The Panel discussed the practical arrangements for the 2016 Legislative Council By-election for the New Territories East Geographical Constituency. [Paper] [Updated background brief prepared by the Secretariat]

On 10 November 2015, the Chief Executive in Council made the Legislative Council Ordinance (Amendment of Schedule 5) Order 2015 in accordance with section 83A of the Legislative Council Ordinance (Cap. 542) to increase the subsidy rate of financial assistance for candidates of Legislative Council ("LegCo") elections; and also the Maximum Amount of Election Expenses (LegCo Election) (Amendment) Regulation 2015 under section 45 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554) to increase the election expenses limits for LegCo elections. The two pieces of subsidiary legislation were gazetted on 13 November 2015 and tabled at LegCo on 18 November 2015 for negative vetting. The House Committee agreed to form a subcommittee to study the Order and the Amendment Regulation. The Subcommittee held a meeting with the Administration and received views from the public on 7 December 2015. The Subcommittee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 18 December 2015. [Meeting schedule] [Report]

The Administration introduced the Electoral Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) (No. 2) Bill 2015 into LegCo on 16 December 2015. The Bill amends various electoral legislation to make necessary technical amendments to align certain deadlines for filing election returns; update the electorate of the Election Committee ("EC") subsectors and the corresponding LegCo functional constituencies; and align the electoral arrangements of the EC subsector elections and the Chief Executive election with the other public elections. The Bills Committee held four meetings and reported to the House Committee on 8 April 2016. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 20 April 2016. The Bill was passed by LegCo on 2 June 2016. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Panel discussed the review on the election expenses limits for the 2016 Election Committee subsector elections and the 2017 Chief Executive election. [Paper] [Background brief prepared by the Secretariat]

On 18 January 2016, the Electoral Affairs Commission ("EAC") made three Amendment Regulations to amend three regulations under the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance (Cap. 541) ("Amendment Regulations"). The amendments aim to improve the voter registration procedures and enhance the fairness and openness of the electoral system. The House Committee agreed to form a Subcommittee to study the Amendment Regulations. The Subcommittee held a meeting to study the Amendment Regulations. The Subcommittee made a report to the House Committee on 26 February 2016.

The Amendment Regulations were tabled at LegCo on 27 January 2016 for negative vetting. The Amendment Regulations came into operation on 18 March 2016. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Government introduced the Maximum Amount of Election Expenses (Chief Executive Election) (Amendment) Regulation 2016, proposing that, the election expenses limit for the Chief Executive ("CE") election will be increased from $13 million to $15.7 million starting from the fifth-term CE election in March 2017. The House Committee did not form a subcommittee to scrutinize the subsidiary legislation.

The subsidiary legislation was tabled at LegCo on 24 February 2016 for negative vetting. The subsidiary legislation came into operation on 15 April 2016.
